dc:title: The woody species of hedges with special reference to age in Church Broughton parish, Derbyshire.
dc:creator: Willmot A.
dc:description: The hedges in one parish in the English Midlands were surveyed to examine the relationship between age and number of woody species. Hedges were aged using maps dating back to 1630 AD. The number of woody species increased by approximately one a century. It is concluded that the number of woody species in hedges is of less value in dating than has been assumed, and should only by used for dating groups of hedges when a local relationship has been established empirically between age and number of species.- from Author

dc:title: The uptake of lead and copper by submerged aquatic macrophytes in two English lakes
dc:creator: Welsh R.P.H.
dc:description: Uptake of lead and copper by nine taxa of submerged aquatic macrophytes from Ullswater and Coniston Water in the English Lake District was investigated by analysis of plant, sediment and water samples collected by sub-aqua diving. Results showed that concentrations of lead and copper were high in the shoots and roots and in the lake sediments, but were low in the lake waters. Positive correlations were found between the metal concentrations in submerged shoots and in the underlying sediments from a range of sample sites; no correlations were found between concentrations in shoots and in lake-water samples, however. The findings are discussed and interpreted in the light of recent experimental data on translocation of metals by submerged water plants. It is concluded that the enrichment of metals in the shoots is largely derived from the high metal concentrations in the sediments. Two pathways for the transfer of metals from the sediments to the shoots are apparent. Lead accumulation in the shoots is considered to be the result of adsorption from the water. Copper accumulation, on the other hand, is considered to be due mainly to absorption by the roots and translocation within the plant to the shoots; direct adsorption from the water into the shoots can also occur.

dc:title: The record of peat wastage in the East Anglian Fenlands at Holme Post, 1848-1978 A.D.
dc:creator: Hutchinson J.
dc:description: Holme Post is a firm datum near the western margin of the East Anglian Fenlands from which the lowering of the peat surface throughout 130 years of drainage has been registered. The observed wastage rates for each stage in the drainage history are summarized. Possible steps are outlined which could contribute towards the amelioration of the current problems arising from peat wastage in the black Fens. -from Author
